fields.description:
Submodule changes are shown by source tree even if the option "ignore = all" is set to a submodule. This is incorrect behaviour and seems to be unsupported.
You can read about this git feature on th eofficial documentation here http://git-scm.com/docs/gitmodules.
You can see a config file example at stackoverflow here
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3240881/git-can-i-suppress-listing-of-modified-content-dirty-submodule-entries-in-sta
fields.summary: Support ignoring submodule changes with ignore flags in git config

fields.description:
I right-clicked the conflict and chose "Resolve using Mine", and yet it appears wrongly in the warning box:

!conflict2.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Resolve Conflict typo - "Mine" appears as "Theirs"

fields.description:
To reproduce:

1. Right click a commit and choose 'Rebase children of ###### interactively'
2. Combine the commits and edit the commit message with a form of unicode characters. (Eg. a Greek word ἄλφα)
3. Successfully rebase it. It'll appear as such:

!unicode2.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Editing Commit Message into a Form of Unicode characters on Interactive Rebase produces Question Marks

fields.description:
Sometimes when you are in a tree view clicking on a folder results in very big delay, because Source Tree is busy generating a diff for every file inside that folder. This delay is also noticeable if you try to scroll through files using down arrow key (there is a small delay for every file, but it is still long enough to notice a studder).

The new feature should include a configurable parameter: how much time you should "focus" on an element in file explorer in order to start generating diff view for that file.
fields.summary: Ability to control the delay between rendering of a diff

fields.description: If you select a reasonably big commit (e.g. 200 files or more) in "Log / History" tree, select "Pending files, sorted by path" ordering, "flat list (single column)" view mode and "Split view staging" and then start to slowly walk through changed files using down arrow key - after some time the "Unstaged files" view will be rapainted and you will loose progress and selected file.
fields.summary: Unstaged files section is repainted randomly

fields.description:
If you move a file, then view history ("Log Selected"), check "Follow renamed files" checkbox and try to view the original file ("Open Selected Version") nothing happens.

*Expected*: an original version of the file is opened, like it does with all changes after the file has been renamed.
fields.summary: Cannot view original file after it has been moved

fields.description:
During some operations (like pull or push) sourcetree opens a dialog to show git output. The font is not fixed size or TABs are not expanded in the same manner so that the text is not aligned as it would appear in a console.
I would like to see the same visual effect of a console (I have copied and paste the dialog text into an editor, all is properly alligned)

Attached a screenshot of what I'm talking about
fields.summary: Show git output using a fixed font size to get text aligned as it is in the console

fields.description: With Full Console Output set to on, it's an annoyance that esc does not close the console window. please map esc to the Close button.
fields.summary: Escape key to close console w/Full Console Output on

fields.description: Opened "create patch" window, removed the checkbox "staged files" => crash
fields.summary: Crash.

fields.description:
How to simulate:
# Open Git options form - menu > Tools > Options > Git.
# Select "current" option in "Push branches" drop-down list.
# Close form by clicking "OK" button.
# Reopen Git options form. "Push branches" drop-down list is back to "matching" option.

It seems to be same issue as this one in Mac version: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1938
fields.summary: Git options form doesn't update "Push branches" setting

fields.description:
When I commit, I dont want to see the full output window as I have to then close the window before I can continue; however longer/remote operations like Push and Pull do necessitate showing the Full Output console so you can see what has happened and its status.

I suggest converting the single one option to either 3 separate options (Show Full Output for [ ] Commit / [ ] Pull / [ ] Push) or a drop-down multi-select list of some description.
fields.summary: Granular "Show Full Output"

fields.description:
When I commit, I dont want to see the full output window as I have to then close the window before I can continue; however longer/remote operations like Push and Pull do necessitate showing the Full Output console so you can see what has happened and its status.

I suggest converting the single one option to either 3 separate options (Show Full Output for [ ] Commit / [ ] Pull / [ ] Push) or a drop-down multi-select list of some description.
fields.summary: Granular "Show Full Output"

fields.description:
My sourcetree gives error after starting.
Have attached the log file.

Please check and let me know the solution asap.
fields.summary: Sourcetree error

fields.description: It is not possible to enter a space to the Destination Path textbox in the Clone Repository dialog - it is instantaneously trimmed (it's possible to insert a space in the middle of a path, but  not at the end)
fields.summary: Git clone destination path with spaces

fields.description:
When trying to create a new repo on Stash via Sourcetree, using the correct Stash credentials, the repo creation will fail, showing the error message: 

"SourceTree was unable to create the remote repository"

:Project ~username does not exist
fields.summary: Cannot Create a Repository via Stash Using Sourcetree

fields.description:
A user reported:

Every now and then moving the vertical splitter gets stuck. The way to make it unstuck is to make SourceTree not be fullscreen and resizing the window. Then you can move the splitter again to make the view showing the file changes bigger.

I haven't been able to find a consistent way to reproduce this. However, I switch between fullscreen and not fullscreen, and also between one of several clones of various source code repositories.

!splitter.png|thumbnail!

Sometimes it gets stuck when intending to move the line to the left.
fields.summary: Splitter in File Status tab gets stuck randomly on different sizes.

fields.description:
Error message when launching sourcetree on Windows 7:

From the windows event viewer:

{code}
Application: SourceTree.exe
Framework Version: v4.0.30319
Description: The process was terminated due to an unhandled exception.
Exception Info: exception code e0434352, exception address 000007FEFCC3B3DD
{code}
fields.summary: Cannot Launch Sourcetree on windows 7

fields.description:
This is a very annoying problem. To reproduce,

# Turn on "fluid staging" and modify any two files.
# Click the checkbox on one file to "add" it to the index.
# Quickly click the checkbox on the other modified file (within a couple of seconds after doing the first action and before the first action is complete).
# The application will no longer refresh the File Status view and l have to restart SourceTree to be able to stage/unstage files again.

The only way to avoid this is to wait for SourceTree to finish staging the first file before attempting to stage any other files.
fields.summary: Adding multiple files to index with SourceTree Git quickly leaves the application unresponsive

fields.description:
When attempting to clone a Mercurial based repository through BitBucket (Clone > Clone in SourceTree), the repository appears to clone and appears in SourceTree but when you try to pull the repository (or do any kind of interaction) the following message is shown:

abort: couldn't parse location ssh:\hg%40bitbucket.org\..........\..........!

See attached screenshot
fields.summary: Cannot add or use Mercurial based BitBucket repositories

fields.description:
SSH allows via config file a entry ID and then a hostname identifier:
Example of my SSH config file:
{quote}
Host entsure
 HostName bitbucket.org
 User bothapn
 PreferredAuthentications publickey
 IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_bitbucket
{quote}

This allows for the case where one would have more than one account at BitBucket (one for work, one for personal) and thus 2 ssh keys. 
This means that the GIT url would need to be:
{quote}ssh://git@entsure/bothapn/entsure.git{quote}

SourceTree in this case does not inspect the config file but rather keeps to the url and then tries to resolve entsure as a hostname which fails.
fields.summary: Not obeying SSH config rules for hostname

fields.description:
Latest commit will look like detached in Commits Graph if the latest commit has a timestamp earlier than its previous commit.

It could happen if the computer which the previous commit (P) is made from has a wrong time (say off by several hours or a day), and the latest commit (L) is made from another computer that has the time properly synced. Now the commit P would have a timestamp like 6/22/2015 13:00, and the commit L would have a timestamp like 6/21/2015/17:00. 

Theoratically, the commit graph should follow the exact relationships between commits, ignoring everything else. For example, command "git log --graph --decorate --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit" will show the graph correctly. However, at least in SourceTree for Windows, the commit graph will not have commit L listed above P. Instead, commit L looks like totally detached from any previous commit.
fields.summary: Latest commit will look like detached in Commits Graph if the latest commit has a timestamp earlier than its previous commit

fields.description: The grey arrow drawn at the right of a submodule icon is still present after pulling the submodule. It suggests that the submodule is not up-to-date while it is. To close the tabsheet and reopen the repository doesn't change anything. To commit and push the changes neither, the wrong visual indication is still there.
fields.summary: submodule grey arrow still drawn after pulling

fields.description: The grey arrow drawn at the right of a submodule icon is still present after pulling the submodule. It suggests that the submodule is not up-to-date while it is. To close the tabsheet and reopen the repository doesn't change anything. To commit and push the changes neither, the wrong visual indication is still there.
fields.summary: submodule grey arrow still drawn after pulling

fields.description:
Let's say you open a git repository with a remote origin and at least 2 branches. In the origin, the two branches contain new commits. 

- Refresh the remote status and the red icon with the commits count is displayed on the *pull* icon. (image 1) 

- Pull the commits for the current branch. The red icon disappears. (image 2)

- Now click to activate the second branch: the red icon is not displayed while there are still some commits to pull. (image3)
fields.summary: red icon not displayed in toolbar after selecting another branch

fields.description: Adding files to stage. (initial commit)
fields.summary: Adding files to stage.

fields.description: When checking out a large branch my SourceTree crashes and asks me to report it here.  This happened about once a day for the last month and I am finally reporting it because it's annoying.
fields.summary: crashes when checking out large branches

fields.description:
The select box for recent commit message has poor UI.

*     No style on mouse hover to distinguish on hovered line
*     Not possible to select by keyboard
*     No separation between message (specially when commit message are multi ligne : maybe display only the 1st line) (see [http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/] about How to Write a Git Commit Message or[ http://karma-runner.github.io/0.12/dev/git-commit-msg.html] for karma commit convention)
fields.summary: Improve Recent Message UI
Crash after Clone process

fields.description:
The exact steps I took to reproduce:

#1 Create a local repository in a Unix environment.
#2 Create a file "test.txt" using vi editor with the this particular content, each word on a separate line:
this
is
a
test
#3 Save the file, and then push the file to a new remote repository (Eg. I did it on Bitbucket).
#4 Clone the repository via SourceTree on Windows. Notice its file status is correctly displayed.

!diff2.PNG|thumbnail!

#5 Now, upload that same file that is in Ubuntu into DropBox
#6 Download the file in Windows, and replace the file that's currently in Windows' local repository.
#7 SourceTree now thinks that the file has changes although there is actually no changes done at all to the file. Plus, this is how it portrays the changes now(not able to view the diff):

!diff.PNG|thumbnail!

#8 Staging the file causes SourceTree to have a slight glitch, and then it disappears from the "Staged files" section, and SourceTree now correctly thinks there's no changes done to the file (the picture in step #4)

-----

Maybe this is related to how SourceTree's very first installation allows us to check/uncheck automatically handling line endings.
fields.summary: A file-transfer from Unix to Windows with no changes done to the file causes the file to be unstaged and its Diff in SourceTree to be empty.

fields.description: See the attached log file
fields.summary: Crash when updating submodule

fields.description:
When dragging around bookmarks, every folder that you drag the bookmark over opens instantly, which is annoying, since I then need to go and close all folders again. 

A very simple fix would be to introduce a delay of say, 1 second, before a folder opens. That way, you could drag bookmarks around, then pause over the folder you wish to put it inside, which will then open.

I have seen this mentioned in several threads, so it seems to be a common problem.
fields.summary: Dragging around bookmarks opens folders

fields.description:
Emoji on Sourcetree commit messages

github supports it.

for instance ":muscle:" must show an arm.
fields.summary: Emoji on Sourcetree commit messages

fields.description:
The suggestion SRCTREEWIN-1461 is nice, but it is an option that destructively deletes ignored files. Those could be valuable configuration files, SSL certificates, index files etc. Ignored files are not per se ignored due to less importance.

The --all option saves the ignored files as well to the stash, which is half-nice, but the better option (since files are not wiped away).

Source: https://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/git-stash.html
fields.summary: Add a checkbox in the Stash dialog for the option  --all

fields.description: When using Explorer context actions such as "Copy as Path" the path tends to be quote wrapped. Allowing the usage of such paths would speed up some workflows.
fields.summary: Allow pasting quote wrapped path for the clone dialog

Application crashes with critical error when a file named <html> (written with the <> - created by human command line failure on a mac and pushed...) is in the repository.
there is no way to not crash the window!

I take the changes from remote

fields.description:
Clicking Help > Check For Updates results in the following error being displayed:

Checking for Updates - Cannot create a file when that file already exists.
fields.summary: Check for updates failing

fields.description: I noticed that when I go to commit a set of staged changes that the "Push changes immediately to ..." checkbox is occassionally checked even though I know I had unchecked it as I prefer to _never_ automatically push commits. What I discovered was that the clickable area for this checkbox extends _all the way_ to the commit button and that I was accidentally clicking the checkbox instead of the commit button. This could be attributed to user error however there is only a few pixels difference between checking the checkbox and pressing the commit button. It would be helpful if the clickable area of the checkbox was limited to the checkbox itself and its text. This would help avoid accidentally pushing commits to our central repo.
fields.summary: Reduce clickable area on the "Push changes immediately..." checkbox in the commit window to avoid accidently clicking this

fields.description:
Currently, the external diff can only be invoked, if one file is selected. I would like to have this changed. I use WinDiff, which supports comparing multiple file pairs at once (-I argument).

Command line help:

{noformat}
Usage:

	windiff [options] path1 [path2]

Options:

-D	Compare one directory only.
-F[flags] savefile	Save composite file to 'savefile'.  The 'flags' may consist of one or more of I (identical), L (left), R (right), F (moved leFt), G (moved riGht), S (Similar left), A (similiAr right), X (exit after saving list).
(e.g. -FLF saves list of Left or moved-leFt lines).
-I file	Reads list of files to compare, from the specified input file.  Each line can contain one or two filenames, space delimited (with quoting, if filenames contain spaces).  Use "-" as the filename to read from stdin.  If a line contains only one filename, the file is compared to itself.
-N name	NET SEND notification to 'name' at end of comparison.
-O	Outline view (no automatic expansion).
-P	Perverse comparison: breaks lines on punctuation.
-S[flags] savefile	Save list of files to 'savefile'.  The 'flags' may consist of one or more of S (same), L (left), R (right), D (different), X (exit after saving list).
(e.g. -SLD saves list of Left or Different files).
-T	Compare whole subtree.
{noformat}
So SourceTree would need to generate a temporary text file, with each line containing two versions of a file (space seperated with quotes around name), as an alternative method, it may copy the files to a temporary location and then compare the temporary and the versioned folders.

While the second one is easier to achieve it is dirty, because it potentially creates a lot of files. Most diff utilities allow the user to edit files, so that would also no longer work.

Implementing the list feature would be a great addition, when you want to compare many files in the project at once to get an overview of all changes.

The External Diff Settings window would need an additional "parameters" input field so a user can define parameters for a multi file compare
fields.summary: Allow Diff of multiple files

fields.description:
The branch/tag labels on the Log/History View seem to have lost their background colours making it difficult to match the labels up with the coloured branch lines.

Also, since the "n ahead" text is white, the lack of any background colour means the text can't actually be read without selecting that line in the history.

Please see attached screenshots for the difference between 1.6.14 and 1.6.15003.
fields.summary: Labels in Log View have no background colour

fields.description:
These are the two files I've pushed to Bitbucket from a Linux OS - same name, just different case formats:

*TesT.txt*
!case3.PNG|thumbnail!

*test.txt*
!case2.PNG|thumbnail!

However, once I cloned the repository into SourceTree on Windows, the two files ended up as just one file, but as if there's changes made by the other file:

!case.PNG|thumbnail!

Expected behavior: SourceTree should detect case-insensitivity problems as it has full control over the repository, it should know if there will be any filename clashes (either by explicitly knowing the filesystem or testing the filesystem by writing a file, then writing with a case-different name and check if there are any clashes.)

When this unintended file modification would occur, SourceTree should display a warning or offer some resolution (whether the problem is in the filenames, or the directory names, resolution could be entirely different)
fields.summary: Pulling two files with same name but different case-format into SourceTree for Windows results in only 1 file, and the second file appearing as the first's modification.
Deneme

fields.summary: Cloning new repository from Hosted Repositories window fails

fields.description:
A user approached us on SourceTree Support:

-----

Hey, Atlassian!

I have been using SourceTree for a while and so far I love it! However the application seems to carelessly use a few hundred megabytes on the disk after first launch. I have deleted some files and it all takes about 10MB now.

Here's a list of what i've noticed that could be improved:
1. The application folder contains 5 megs of .pdb files. Did you intend to ship all that debug data to the end user? Removing them shrinked the application folder size from ~15mb to ~10mb. The installer size would most likely benefit as well.

2. The application does not clean up the git and mercurial distribution archives from \AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree after installation, but ideally, it should. That's about 30MB saved.

3. Lastly, and most importantly, please add the "remove embedded" buttons for embedded git and hg distributions. SourceTree downloads them both at first launch. Unpacked they take about 300MB in total. But some people might not need neither one. (I don't use hg and I use my own git folder) Removing the folders manually seems to work fine. Why not add a button for that purpose?
fields.summary: Improvement Request: Reduce disk space used by SourceTree

fields.description: SourceTree chashes when navigating to a specific commit in the history. It looks that there is an invalid filename in the commit, which was committed from git on Linux. This filename now seems to crash SourceTree on Windows.
fields.summary: Crash on Illegal characters in path

fields.description:
In the commit dialog, there is "Push changes immediately to ..." checkbox.

Although my current branch (let's say master) tracks origin/master, this dialog says "Push changes immediately to differentRemote/master". Furthermore there does not need to be branch master on the differentRemote at all.

The logic seems to be to push to random remote (?) and to the branch that has same name as local branch. The logic should be to push to tracked remote and branch.
fields.summary: "Push changes immediately to ..." doesn't use correct branch

fields.description:
In the commit dialog, there is "Push changes immediately to ..." checkbox.

Although my current branch (let's say master) tracks origin/master, this dialog says "Push changes immediately to differentRemote/master". Furthermore there does not need to be branch master on the differentRemote at all.

The logic seems to be to push to random remote (?) and to the branch that has same name as local branch. The logic should be to push to tracked remote and branch.
fields.summary: "Push changes immediately to ..." doesn't use correct branch

fields.description: When deleting a GIT repository from SourceTree, it leaves behind an empty directory with a .git folder inside of it.  This prevents re-pulling the repository from the remote until that directory is deleted, or unless i download to a new location.
fields.summary: Deleting local repo leaves empty directory

fields.description: If a trailing whitespace character is present on the source url line in the git clone dialog, an error occurs ("This is not a valid url"). Automatically removing trailing whitespaces would prevent this unexpected behaviour.
fields.summary: Automatically remove trailing whitespaces for clone->source url textbox

fields.description:
In SourceTree 1.6.15003 beta, clicking the Terminal button causes SourceTree to crash and terminate itself.

A fatal error is recorded in sourcetree.log (see attached).

This seems to occur regardless of whether embedded or system git is selected, but can be worked around to some extent by unchecking "Use Git Bash as default terminal" in SourceTree's Git options.

P.S. I've followed the help text on issue priorities but I'm not sure this particular issue really is critical. Someone can change this to minor if more appropriate.
fields.summary: Terminal button crashes SourceTree with fatal error

fields.description:
Every time SourceTree 1.6.15003 starts up, the bookmarks panel resizes itself to fill half the width of the screen.

If the bookmarks panel was hidden when SourceTree was last exited, then upon the next run there will instead be a blank grey space taking up half the screen (see screenshot).

The only way to get rid of this blank space seems to be to show the bookmarks panel, then resize the panel, then hide it again. Simply showing then hiding does not work; the resize seems to be required.
fields.summary: SourceTree starts with bookmarks panel or blank space filling half the screen

fields.description: "Push changes immediately..." checkbox is checked even when not hitting anywhere close to it, which can cause accidental push up to remote - especially when it can still be checked right at the left side of the commit button.
fields.summary: "Push changes immediately..." checkbox is checked even when not hitting anywhere close to it.

fields.description:
Sometimes I work on multiple JIRAs/TASKS under the same branch, I have to code and constantly test integration. 

For the sake of generating different multiple pull requests (1 per JIRA/Feature) if I can just right click file/line and generate a brand new Branch from develop/master with that file change. 
This way, I can work one branch, test and then split my changes in multiple branches/pull requests for review without going through the painfully slow sourcetree branch swtiches.
fields.summary: Create Branches out of File changes

fields.description: It should be possible to set a scope for custom actions, e.g. "repository", "commit", "file". For example a custom action that runs git clean on the whole repository should not be available from the commit tree menu.
fields.summary: Custom action context

fields.description: If I create a custom action and run it while I have selected a folder the custom action gets the first file in the folder and not the folder itself as "$FILE". It should be possible somehow to create custom actions with folders.
fields.summary: Custom actions with folders not working

fields.description:
In the log history, sorting by 'Path alphabetically' is case-sensitive but shouldn't be. For example, it displays in this order:

Root/Sample
Root/example

Instead of:

Root/example
Root/Sample

fields.description: Sourcetree does not seem to support the 64-bit build of git for windows from the git-for-windows.github.io "Git For Window" project, which seems to be the new successor to Msys-Git and the most up to date version of Git for Windows. fields.description:
When i apply git diff patch with mode set to "import as full commit" and the dry run check box is checked, i get the message saying that the dry run was a success and i should apply the patch without the dry run check box checked.

*Step to recreate the situation : *
- Apply a patch with a mode different from "import as full commit", with the dry run checked.
- Then choose the "import as full commit" mode. The check box will disabled but it will remain checked.

Now at this stage, the commit actually get added to my commits history and the files are modified but i get the message when the dry run check box is checked.

*The way i see it there is two solutions : *
1- Do not consider the dry run check box status when use the mode "import as full commit"
2- When the mode "import as full commit" is selected, automatically uncheck the dry run check box.

NB : I tested it on the 1.6.14 version, i don't know about earlier versions.
fields.summary: Apply patch, import as full commit

fields.description:
Selecting a commit including the rename of a path from ~300 chars to ~220 makes the SourceTree GUI crash.

My setup:
- create a new git repo on linux/macosx
- create a file with a relative path (to the git root) longer than 260 chars
- commit and push to remote (if any)
- on Windows clone the previous project (and you will get an error with source tree)
- on linux rename the path to a shorter one and commit+push
- on windows you can clone now but if you click on the commit, SourceTree crashes

Maybe you could use another API call with the path format that can handle 32k chars:
e.g. \\?\d:\myLongPath...

fields.description:
I'm a little new to Git, and I'm still internalizing the various branching workflows.  In every guide to these workflows, you'll see branches like "master", "develop", and "release" sticking in one column in their diagrams - for an example, see here: http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/ I think this kind of diagram is awesome, and really easy to follow.

That's why I think it'd be awesome if I could tell SourceTree to do something like one of these:
-Always display the release branch on the far left, then the master branch, then the develop branch, then all other branches
-Sort the branches
-Drag and drop the branches to reorder them

I've never seen a DSCM GUI tool that has this feature; you guys would be the first!

Anyway - I love SourceTree so far, keep up the great work!

Thanks!
fields.summary: In the branch graph, it'd be great if we could dictate the positions of the branches

fields.description:
The bookmark panel used to be nicely sized to the left, but now has somehow increased to completely fill the window. Turning the panel on and off works, but does not resize it so that I can view the repo tabs and the bookmark pane at the same time.

If there is a config file I can edit to fix the issue in the mean time I'd appreciate directions.

Thanks! :)
fields.summary: Bookmarks panel fills window

fields.description:
Use case: 

* User is using the connector between Jira and Stash (or Bitbucket or Github) and wants the commits to show up in the issue. 
* User is using the feature branch workflow and putting the Jira issue key into his branch names.
* User makes changes and starts commit in ST.
* Desired result: Jira issue key is automatically prefilled into the commit message.

Solution: Create a configuration option like "Prefill commit message from branch" which takes a regular expression as value. The part of the branch name that matches the expression gets extracted and put in the commit message. Note that the solution isn't hardcoded to Jira or Stash/Bitbucket/Github/..., and hence will work with other issue trackers or indeed any piece of information that can be sensibly copied from the branch name into the commit message.

See discussion at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/16388104/how-to-get-the-issue-key-into-the-commit-message-automatically.
fields.summary: If branch contains a string matching a regular expression in an configuration option, prefill commit message with string.

fields.description:
I had a project that switched origins. I used the Repository Settings area to change the remote "origin" to the new URL. (Honestly, I don't remember if I removed the old origin and added a new one or just changed the URL for the existing origin.)

Now, when I go to create a pull request, it auto-selects the old origin URL in the "Submit via remote" dropdown. I can choose the correct, new origin from that dropdown and create the pull request in the right project, but it's a nuisance. I'd rather remove the old remote reference from the "Submit via remote" dropdown.

Information that might help:
* We're using Stash for our remote
* The old remote still exists (for now)
* No other references to the old remote can be found either through the SourceTree UI or the .git/config file
* I'm on Windows 8.1

Let me know what other information I can provide.
fields.summary: "Create pull request..." sees old remotes

Upon clicking search it popped up with the message saying to create a ticket and let you know what I could.  Hopefully this helps.  I have also attached the log file.

fields.description: Within Bitbucket when you merge a pull request and have it automatically close the branch the repo only shows the of active branches. However, in SourceTree, if I fetch from the remote, it shows all the branches. This list is getting huge since we use Jira to create branches for all our issues. I really don't want to have to delete all the remote branches. SourceTree should reflect the branches just like Bitbucket does.

fields.description:
Every time I try to open a bookmarked repo, SourceTree crashes. I was able to reproduce it and there are two times logged in the attached log. I initially couldn't get SourceTree to launch until I removed the opentabs.xml from my AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree directory.

Removing the repo bookmark and re-adding it, I'm able to access it and SourceTree doesn't crash. I don't want to have to re-add it every time I open SourceTree though.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when trying to open a GIT repo

fields.description:
I updated my git version 1.9.5 (mysysgit - https://msysgit.github.io/)
to 2.4.1 (https://github.com/git-for-windows/git/releases/tag/v2.4.1.windows.1)

After the git update I started SourceTree and it said that it can't find git (see screenshot attachment).
If I select "Browse to the location of git on your system" nothing happens. The "Git not found" dialog will popup again and again. It doesn't let me select the path.

So I took a look at the git installation folder and the SourceTree user.config  and realized that SourceTree only stores the path to the git installation folder. Not the path to the git executable. E.g.

 <setting name="GitSystemPath" serializeAs="String">
         <value>C:\Program Files\Git</value>
  </setting>

So SourceTree depends on the structure of the git installation directory and this structure changed from 1.9.5 to 2.4.1.

In *1.9.5* the git executable is located in *GIT_INSTALL_FOLDER/bin*
In *2.4.1* the git executable is located in *GIT_INSTALL_FOLDER/cmd*


*Workaround*
I just created a junction GIT_INSTALL_FOLDER/bin that points to GIT_INSTALL_FOLDER/cmd and it worked. 
(See the workaround screenshot attachment)
The junction was created using http://schinagl.priv.at/nt/hardlinkshellext/linkshellextension.html.
fields.summary: Support for "Git for Windows 2.4.x"

fields.description:
This is more a general feedback, the UI seems to have a certain latency when performing user action.
The most annoying is for example when changing tabs for repository. Just after clicking on the tab seems to wait for about 500ms - 1s before to display the actual content.
This makes the UI heavy and not pleasant at all.

Compared to a well known tab browsing experience such as a web browser the tab is switched instantly, the content is then loaded. In the case of SourceTree it feels like it's the inverse (click, content loaded, then switch to tab)

Unfortunately this kind of behavior can be often reproduced on UI component
fields.summary: UI Latency (especially tabs)

fields.description:
"When I try to clone a project from my gitolite server using the following URL:

ssh://git@git.cs.kysu.edu/myproject

SourceTree sends my default login name (jh), not the requested one (git) and as such the authentication succeeds (because the correct private key is loaded) but of course the wrong shell is executed. I can see the communication in my server's logs. Everything works fine on the Mac, which is my main OS (I use Windows for teaching only). No default usernames or saved passwords are set in Options->Authentication."

More info:

"I try to clone git@git.cs.kysu.edu:ksu-invaders (one of my demo games). The server logs show the following:

Mar 18 09:00:09 cs-git sshd[28789]: Accepted publickey for jh from 166.177.187.166 port 49303 ssh2: RSA d1:85:20:e2:f2:06:b5:fd:f7:74:af:f0:8d:fc:d2:f9
Mar 18 09:00:09 cs-git sshd[28789]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user jh by (uid=0)
Mar 18 09:00:09 cs-git systemd-logind[627]: Removed session 2492.

The key is correct. But the username is not. It should be git, not jh. (I do have a login account on the server, too).

Again, as stated in my previous comment, I assume what's happening here is that, on first SourceTree setup, I accidentally used jh@git and not git@git, and that info somehow got stuck with SourceTree (or jh, as it is my default windows username, gets sent every single time). On fresh setups (completely new virtual machine) with correct initial setup this doesn't happen."
fields.summary: SourceTree ignores/sends wrong login name using the ssh:// protocol

fields.description: Git for Windows provides Git Bash as an alternative to the Windows command line. When using system git instead of embedded git, it would be great if SourceTree had an option to use Git Bash when I click the "Terminal" button.
fields.summary: Option to open Git Bash with the "Terminal" button

fields.description:
No matter what configuration options I try, SourceTree will not launch the external diff tool. I have tried the following:
* BeyondCompare (v3.3)
* Custom (BeyondCompare manual configuration)
* DiffMerge (v4.2.0)

Some of my colleagues are also experiencing this issue. This is a major headache especially for conflict resolution.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not launch external diff tool

fields.description:
If "Display full console output" is enabled, output contains a lot of empty lines. Basically more lines with text it contains, more empty lines are before "Completed successfully" message, so you have to scroll down a lot to see if an operation was successful.

Would it be possible to just strip empty lines from the output? (for example leave only 1 empty line on its place and remove others).

In screenshot, only first half of output contains lines with text, the other half contains empty lines only.
fields.summary: Strip blank lines from full console output

fields.description: I currently program in both C# and LabVIEW. C# uses the standard merge/diff tools, but LabVIEW is a graphical language and needs specialized merge/diff. I can set these up in SourceTree, but then C# does not work. At the moment, I would need to set up a shell which calls the appropriate diff/merge based on the file type. It would be nice if SourceTree allowed me to do this natively. This is a normal part of most source control clients I have used in the past (e.g. Perforce).
fields.summary: Support Multiple Diff/Merge For Multiple File Types

fields.description:
Two projects (A & B) include a third (C) via individual subtrees within those projects.

Project C is updated and pushed to remote. Subtree in Project A is pulled from Project C remote.

Then switched to Project B tab. Right click subtree and selected pull of Project C remote. It appears that nothing is happening. Switched to Project A tab and Project C is being pulled again.

fields.description:
I want to have pre-defined commit message style for all my co-workers for a project I am working.

It would be very helpful if templates are available for commit messages or if it possible for a user to define a template and export it to file which can be imported to commit message box.

The template can have support for:
- The names of committed files so that a separate message per file describing the change in that file can be written.
- Lines-Of-Code changed.
- Reviewed by
- Type of commit (Types will be user defined: BUG_FIX, FEATURE, TEST_CODE, etc.)
fields.summary: Template for commit messages

fields.description: In git, you can add custom renderers or text converters to handle specific file extensions. One of which is really useful is docx2txt. It converts the text of a Microsoft Word DOCX file to text for diff'ing. After adding entries to the .gitconfig and .git/info/attributes file, it's usable on the command line fairly easily. I'd like to be able to use this extensibility on the SourceTree GUI, where I spend most of my time diff'ing and committing.
fields.summary: Allow external diff engines for a particular filetype (docx2txt)
